video.title: Writing Code like a Real Hacker (VS Code Macro Extension)
video.description:
How To Become A 10x Programmer With This One Simple Trick...

What you will really learn about is a great VS Code extension that allows you to create macros and is useful for live coding.

Presented by Jani Eväkallio - Formidable Labs
Twitter: https://twitter.com/jevakallio

Talk by Jani Eväkallio at the Reactive London October 2018 meetup.

Recorded by Pusher.com. Thanks to Pusher for giving us permission to post this talk.

Pusher's channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCoyqucxoFXDFnh3khD0rjUg

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Lord Royce
topLevelComment.text:
Me and my brain: Halfway through the video i was already planning how to improve my code writing speed to this level. Basically I was just setting my goal....thank god I watched till the end or I wouldve ventured into a pretty bad journey. 
Touch typing rocks though, took me a month to get to 80 WPM. Try it...its so fast.

replies.author: Ty johnston
replies.text: @dCode You called me out lol. I'm "self taught" and a noob. Only been at it 6months and that's my base. Quoted self taught because one day I dove in trying to understand some base64 I ran across on an itunes backup db. Didn't know what I was even looking at but needed to know. Seen a SQLite 3 as a header, Googled this strange "document", aaand here I am 6months later watching this video while utilizing VSC writing Python for an SQLite injection for some database on my other computer I'm accessing. I never knew how diverse the programming world had to be. I thought I would learn SQLite and know what I wanted to know.  Crazy the different languages and levels for a "simple" OS such as a phone.

topLevelComment.author: Vaughn Kottler
topLevelComment.text:
Just use Vim. This feature is native, just press 'q', hit another key as the key to save the macro to, perform your keystrokes, press 'q' again and to execute the macro press '@' followed by the key you recorded it to.

Do any non-script kiddies use this editor?

replies.author: Jani Eväkallio
replies.text: It's not quite the same as vim macros in that the hacker typer macro is meant to simulate real typing by advancing the macro buffer one char on each keypress. This is meant for live coding and such. No doubt you could do this in vim too, of course.

replies.author: Zelnoth
replies.text: It's an extension called "vscode power mode". It's based of an effect in the codeinthedark editor.  Sadly it's not that good in vs code due to it  being hard to access some of the elements, for instance the original has a combo meter as well. If anyone is using atom there's and extension there called "activate power mode" which is pretty great.

replies.author: Erin D
replies.text:
​@Manuel Koza agreed. Some people are idiots. Hack's just using things in unconventional ways in which it was not originally intended. A "Spring Cleaning Hack" might be something like: 'using vinegar in place of Ammonia (Windex) to wash windows - bye bye dirty streaks...'


Hacking tech takes a LOT of learning in many fundamental areas of tech, and even then, people specialize. Every hacker learns basic concepts in: Hardware & Software, OSs-- Linux, Bash command line, Kali + tools, Android, Windows, iOS, Apple; Git; Development; DBs--SQL noSQL; XML; languages (basics like HTML, CSS JS- the building blocks of the web + PHP),  Python, node.js for server-side JS (like Web apps and back end dev);  virtualization; and finally --how Servers (physical, virtual, public, hybrid / private clouds) work to get, give and store data is crucial knowledge to have.  How a person uses their skills denotes the type of Hacks they can pull off, and for what purpose  they hack is what makes them a White, Grey and/or Black Hat Hacker.  Many companies, orgs and governments employ hackers of all types to help them analyze, theorize, contain and combat threats.

replies.author: Shawn Ritchie
replies.text:
@Issa Rukayat download a version of centos and learn the basic concepts of programming by scripting. The first thing to do is learn how to navigate, so find some pictures of a centos file structure, and practice hopping around. maybe even try using .. and .   (you probably have no clue what im talking about but its super simple)


basically, scripting in linux is just making a text file that has a list of commands to run, but with this, you can also use conditional aswell. you can use if, do-while, etc... its pretty fun just to dick around with.

replies.author: Issa Rukayat
replies.text: @bibibobs I didn't start from php. I have done all that u listed. Thanks alot. I have Ampps.. I am on OOP. I  know html, css, a little bit of JavaScript, bootstrap. And I have built a form connected to database using PHP. (CRUD)

replies.author: bibibobs
replies.text: @Issa Rukayat You gotta start at the boring stuff... HTML > CSS > JS (Look for modern tutorials that say 'ES6' or 'ES7') PHP (Not OOP yet) > SQL (Download xampp) > now start learning the principles of OOP, this applies to most languages, if you've learned OOP you can start creating real applications, but I'd recommend picking up a JS framework (Vue, React, Etc...) And Node.js. After all this you've became a fullstack web dev! :) Now you can switch to other languages like Java, C# or what ever you like, the main difference is that Java & C# are strong typed and require types (what does it take: String, int, boolean?) What does it return? (List<TYPE>, float, void?)
